Steve Prefontaine: American Distance Legend

"To give anything less than your best is to sacrifice the gift"

A Brief Outline of Steve Prefontaine's Life:

  • January 1951 - Steve Roland Prefontaine is born on the 25th in Coos Bay, Oregon.
  • August 1965 - Joins the Marshfield High School cross country team.
  • June 1969 - Last high school race. Throughout his Junior and Senior year, Pre had been undefeated.
  • June 1969 - Prefontaine starts his collegiate career at the University of Oregon, where he trained under Bill Bowerman. During his time as a Duck, Pre went on to:
  • Four consecutive NCAA DI national titles in the 3 Mile race, Pre was the first NCAA athlete to accomplish this feat.
  • Three national titles at the NCAA DI Cross Country Championships (1970,1971,1973).
  • A 3rd place podium finish at the NCAA DI Cross Country Championships in 1969 during his Freshman year.
  • A fifth place spot in the 5K during his first international competition: USA vs USSR (1969).
  • Undefeated in any collegiate event on the track 3 miles and over.He had only lost in the mile race three times by the time he had graduated.
  • Featured on the cover of Sports-Illustrated in 1970
  • July 1972 -Prefontaine won the Olympic Trials 5000m race in 13:22.8; setting an American Record in the process.
  • September 1972 -The "Munich Massacre" occurs at the Olympic Village. 11 Israeli athletes are killed by a Palestinian terrorist group. After a breif stop, the Olympic games continue. Pre winds up finsihing 4th place in the 5000m; narrowly missing a podium finish by .64 seconds.
  • January 1974 -Prefontaine joined the Oregon Track Club. While there, Pre set American records in every event from the 2000m to the 10,000m. This, along with the success of fellow runners such as Frank Shorter, helped kick off the "running boom".
  • May 1975 - On May 29th, Pre runs his final race; winning the 5000m. Driving home that evening after a party, Pre dies in a car crash. He was 24.
  • June 1975 - A few days after Pre's death, the first inaugural Prefontaine Classic is held. It is now the longest running track and field meet in America.

"Some people create with words or with music or with a brush and paints. I like to make something beautiful when I run. I like to make people stop and say, 'I've never seen anyone run like that before.' It's more than just a race, it's a style. It's doing something better than anyone else. It's being creative."-Steve Prefontaine

To learn more about Steve Prefontaine's accolades, story and influence, follow this link to read more on Runner's World.
